Award.AwardTitle: Participant Support for the Third Fundamental Neutron Physics Summer School will be held at TRIUMF, Vancouver, Canada
Award.AbstractNarration:
"Fundamental Neutron Physics'' is an experimental subfield of "Fundamental Symmetries," which addresses core problems of particle physics through the use of precision measurements, often involving polarized atoms and nuclei. These experiments generally use low-energy facilities and techniques including neutron beams, ultra-cold neutrons, polarized sources and and laser-physics tools. The Fundamental Neutron Physics Summer School has the aim of bringing together graduate students and young post docs entering the field with professionals who provide lectures that give a comprehensive overview of the theoretical foundations and motivations, the basic principles and physics that underlie our understanding of the neutron sources and neutron beams, and specific topics represented by the suite of experiments ongoing and planned.

The Fundamental Neutron Physics Summer School will take place as part of the TRIUMF Summer Institute (TSI 2012), August 6-16, 2012, at TRIUMF in Vancouver, BC. The curriculum of TSI 2012 will include a broad introduction to the particle theory of the Standard Model and Beyond Standard Model Physics that motivates research in fundamental neutron physics, muon physics and neutron physics. The fundamental neutron physics curriculum will include introductory material on neutron sources, neutron optics and polarization techniques. From there, experiments including electric dipole moment (EDM), interferometry, gravitational interaction and hadronic parity violation will present the breadth of research currently underway as well as prospects for the future. The capstone lecture will challenge the lecturer and students to consider where these fields will be a decade from now. Thirty-one lectures will be presented by 24 lecturers. In addition, homework and breakout discussion sections will round out the school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2012 TRIUMF Summer Institute (TSI) is the most recent offering of the celebrated series of schools focusing on a broad view of an improtant subfield of physics. for advanced graduate students and recent PhD recipients. The topic for the 2012 TSI was Fundamental Symmetries and Fundamental Neutron Physics. Fundamental Symmetries is the field that addresses precission measurements in atomic, nuclear and particle physics that probe the interatctions of physics at very short range, normally addressable only in high-energy collider physics experiments. By measuring very small effects with great sensitivity and exploting the "symmetry signatures" of observables, very weak forces can be studied. For example the symmetry of physics under mirror reflection is not perfect, and the small breaking of this symmetry reveals the weak interaction's effect on atomic structure. Even weaker, as yet undiscovered forces are probed in combining mirror-symmetry with the reversal of time. Fundamental Neutron Physics is, quite simply, the study of the fundamental symmetries of the neutron's interactions and decay. Studies of neutrinos as they change form and the search for dark matter in experiments built deep underground to shield the sensitive detectors from cosmic rays are other examples.

TSI 2012 was attended by 45 students from the US, Canada, Europe and Asia. Lectures were presented by 23 leaders in the field on the topics Cosmology and Baryogenesis, The Standard Model and Beyond, Dark Matter, Fundamental Muon Physics, Neutrino Oscillations and
Neutrino Astronomy as well as Fundamental Neutron Physics. Daily homewrok assignments consisting of problems provided by each lecturer were provided for students wishing to receive univeristy credit for attending.In addition to tours of the TRIUMF reserach facilities, there were two outings to enjoy the culture and natural beauty of the Vancouver area. 

The 45 attendees of TSI 2012 represent the core of the future members of the field. They received a broad and deep introduction to the current status of the field, ongiong efforts in theroy and experiment and a glimpse of where the field is headed and how thay can take part. Evaluations of the Summer Instittute provided by the attendees were uniformly positive and provided valuable feedback for planning future such schools and the next Fundamental Neutron Physics School.
